public class  Progress
     extends java.awt.Frame
{
          // Constructors 1
     public Progress(String, int);

          // Methods 13
     public static void main(String[]);

     public boolean action(Event, Object);
     public void advance();
     protected void build();
     public boolean canceled();
     public int current();
     public boolean handleEvent(Event);
     public void paint(Graphics);
     protected void paintBar();
     public int percentComplete();
     protected int pixelsComplete();
     public void setMessage(String);
     public int total();
}

A general purpose progress bar dialog box that shows percentage completion of some long running operation, and allows the user to cancel. Clients of this code should construct a Progress object with a header and an integer for the total amount of work that will be done. Then do their own processing, calling advance() every so often. Eventually, the number of advance() calls should equal the total amount of work specified in the constructor call.

See Also: Preloader, uci.gef.Example




  Constructors

· Progress

Summary  |  Top 

   public Progress(String header, 
                   int total)

Construct a new Progress object.

Parameter Description
header Describes the long running task.
total Number of units of work needed to complete the task.



  Methods

· advance

Summary  |  Top 
   public void advance()

Client code calls advance() from inside the code for its long term task whenever one unit of work is completed. The number of calls shuold equal the total work specified in the contructor.

Summary  |  Top 
   public int current()

Return amount of work done so far

Returns total work to be done

· action

Summary  |  Top 
   public boolean action(Event e, 
                         Object what)

Checks to see if the user clicked the cancel button. It is the client class's responsibility to check the canceled flag and hide and dispose of this window when the operation in progress is canceled.
